Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: How to think logically
Logical deduction, and abstract thinking.

I learned what logic is and sort of how to construct arguments (although I wish we could've focused more on this rather than sentence letters and such so that what we learned could be more applicable to everyday life for non-philosophy majors).

I've never taken anything like this, so I learned a ton. First-order logic stresses the idea that arguments are valid by the nature of their form, and we spent a lot of time paraphrasing sentences into logical abstractions we could then manipulate and compare. I took this course hoping for an easy QR, and although the problem sets took longer than I had expected, I generally really enjoyed them. Not totally sure how this class would help me in the future or tie into my other coursework, but it was fun and different.
I learned a lot about logic, and I feel like I'll actually retain the knowledge because the weekly quiz format required me to internalize information each week.

I learned how to solve mathematical logic. The material in this class is such that it's very hard to imagine how it would be useful outside of the realm of this class, but it did improve my "logical thinking" which can be helpful in a variety of settings.
I learned how to recognize and construct logically valid arguments. This is a good course for learning how to schematize the nuances of our language in a systemized way.
I learned about how to think about sentences and logical arguments. Learned how to interpret sentences and then tell if they are true or not based on other arguments.

In this course, I learned how to break down an argument into a set of premises to deduce whether that argument was in fact truth functionally logical. Also I learned how to determine whether or not a set of premises imply a conclusion and how to use a set of rules and premises to deduce a conclusion.
Logical paraphrase, concepts of sentential logic, deduction
I learned the basics of sentential and quantificational deductive logic.
I learned how to analyze the logical structure of various statements.
I learned the basic skills of first-order logical thinking and reasoning. I developed a better logical way of thinking myself.
A new way of thinking. Logic is unlike any quantitative reasoning I've done before, and I appreciate the new framework.
understanding of logical notation, logical and deductive reasoning.

I went into the class having basically no idea what logic was or how it could be used. Now, I have a solid understanding of what first-order logic consists of and also how its formalism can be applied to the construction of verbal and written arguments. I have a very solid grasp on all of the fundamental symbols and functions upon which logical arguments are formed, including conjunctions, disjunctions, conditionals, biconditionals, and various combinations of these. I also have learned how to successfully do sentential deduction. I struggled a bit with developing the skills needed for the second half of the course, which consisted of quantificational paraphrase, interpretation, and deduction.

Learned about formal systems of logic. Connection to "real life" for those not interested in pursuing further classes in logic is tenuous, though if someone has not had prior exposure to rigorous critical thinking in a formal manner this could definitely prove useful.
I learned Goldfarbian Logic!
Improved my learning skill by systematically learning a new mathematical language.

I learned how to break down an argument to its logical structure and see if it holds. Though it is tempting to see this class as self contained (meaning, the things you learn don't relate to anything outside the class), that is not at all true!
I learned to boil down ideas and arguments into their precise logical form.

Though it might not seem immediately applicable to real life, this course is definitely useful. Being able to think logically is crucial to success in almost any field, and it definitely helps on LSAT, GMAT, etc. Also - though I have never heard it advertised for this purpose - I think it serves as a great introduction to proof-based mathematics for those who haven't taken any yet.

I became a very logical thinker!!! First-Order Logic was an amazing class. I especially appreciate that this course made me think more about the importance of clarity and specificity in language (I'm an English major so this was really cool for me).
This course is a fun and interesting window into how we ought to, and how we do, think about things in a formal sense.
I learned so much about logic, a subject I hadnt been exposed to before. It is great for problem solving and argument building.

I definitely learned a new method of thinking-- that sounds weird but I had to train myself to think in a different way than I normally do for this class. I think it will be useful in day-to-day reasoning.
I actually learned logical thinking that is very helpful and gave me a new insight into forms of posing statements and arguments and thinking about them and their validity.
This is an intellectually-challenging course. You learn the basics of basic and quantificational logic, which lays the foundations for further study of math or computer science.
logical thinking, deduction, critical thinking,

Though Im not sure if I will remember all of the paraphrasing and deduction rules, the main thing that will stick with me from this class is how to construct arguments. I feel as though I walk away from the class a better writer and reasoner despite the fact that it was a QR credit

When I was shopping this course, the responses to this question were all "I learned first-order logic," and in hopes of not being a lil shit like that, I'm going to actually make a list of things we learned:
- how to pull apart English sentences to examine the underlying logical structure
- how to schematize English sentences into logical structures
- how to represent ideas/parts of arguments in a logical framework (which looks a lot like variables from math)
- how to manipulate logical structures to understand how argumentation works on a sentence level, regardless of content
- deduction (i.e. how one argumentative structure can be derived from another) and deduction with quantifiers
- and more

Insights: 
- definitely got a peek behind the structure of the English language, and the inherent math in the logic of an argument

Skills:
- I keep comparing things to math because I felt like I was relearning basic math, just with a different set of rules. I'm sure this will come in handy when it comes to thinking about regular English sentences but from a programming or legal perspective
You learn the theory behind valid argumentation through logic. In terms of real life application, the idea is you learn how to form logically sound arguments.
I learned a lot about logic!! It was a really in depth and comprehensive introduction to logic.
You learn a whole new language and ways to test the logical validity of arguments!
I learned fundamental deductive logic. I learned so much it was incredible.
How to think critically and logically.

Professor Miller describes it as exercise for your brain, and it is. This isn't the class if you want to learn hard skills (unless maybe for the LSAT?) but it's logic, and it's something that I think is a great practice. This is especially true if you're a humanities/social sciences major/most of your classes involve lots of reading it's a great respite to have a class that is a pset class.
I learned about deductive reasoning and how to account for nuances in the English language when paraphrasing statements into logical statements.

As someone who does not intend on seriously pursuing a career in philosophy, I do not believe that the skills I gained from this class will be useful to me. I did gain a better understanding of how logical arguments are structured.
Logic
How to reason
How to think clearer, as well as the various form of logic introduced. More of a skills-based course than a knowledge acquiring one.
Basic logic skills.
basic concepts in logic, basic logical notation, application of logical mapping to natural language, basics of deduction, quantificational and truth functional logic.
Other than the actual logic concepts themselves, I would say I gained a greater precision in looking at how sentences work, and how conclusions can be deduced from certain premises.
I have been properly introduced to the field of logistics, and some of the elementary rules used to develop complex logical statements in future courses.
How to assess the validity of statements relative to truth-functional and quantificational logic.
Logic is incredibly challenging but also very rewarding. In this course I was taught the skills and methods of logic and also the thinking behind everything we did.

Crash course in the basics of formalized logic structures. Very interesting stuff, but also quite alien and unintuitive. The only thing that made the course and material accessible, endurable, and (most of the time) enjoyable was the inimitable Elizabeth Miller; we were truly some lucky ducks to have her as our instructor. Elizabeth was incredibly adept at explaining difficult concepts, and was always willing to go above and beyond to make sure we had what we needed to perform at our best, as a class and as individuals. My advice to anyone considering taking the class without Elizabeth is to be sure you enroll during a semester when there's a decent human being teaching it.
Learned how to think logically
This course helped me develop clearer thought and stronger logical reasoning abilities.
what it means to think logically
I learned how to speak on the language of deductive logic, how to do truth tables, how to break down every day language into basic truths, and how to think more logically about my everyday language.
This class was great for learning the basics of logical notations and structure. While it was very technical, it had interesting applications to the real world.
A basic grasp of logical structure and deduction!
basic understanding of logical systems, how to check for logical arguments
I learned how to think logically about everyday speech and how to tease apart the elements of my own arguments so they are as clear and concise as possible.
Anality!

Logic developed my ability to think -- it made my brain work in a different way than normal. I learned how to paraphrase sentences into logical notation and how to perform deductions: how to prove that one thing implies another using a limited set of tools that a "mindless recipe follower" could follow. More broadly, I gained a better ability to think about the components of language and arguments.

By taking this course, I developed my critical thinking and reasoning skills. I also learned that I had to take advantage of the resources offered in order to do well in this course, and keep up with the week-to-week so as not to fall behind.

I had never taken logic before this course and I now feel that I have the tools to understand the mechanics behind arguments and logical statements, which has certainly helped me in the philosophy course I'm taking alongside logic.
The ability to solve a variety of first order logic problems.
I learned how to think logically and write in logical notation.
I learned that language can be a fallible way of communicating logical truths.
I developed a greater knowledge for logic and thinking/argue mental skills.
Logic helped me understand the underlying principles of language and argument.
Developed an understanding of truth-functional logic, quantifiers, and formal deduction
I learned boolean logic, how to do basic deductions, and how to schematize sentences into its logical structure.

Strength: Easy A, Easy Quizzes, Easy Final
Weakness: None, Prof Miller is probably the best professor I've ever had
Great slides that were interactive and understandable, and a great, engaging teacher that answered any questions.

Our lecture was absolutely huge - we had to move from LC102 to SSS114. Although Elizabeth is a great professor, it's just too easy to zone out, check your phone, or skip the lecture altogether, so I saw the size of this course as a definite weakness. The problem sets were fun and helpful, as were discussions. Most of the course grade comes from weekly quizzes, which could be stressful and took a lot of time to prepare for. I wish we had graded problem sets instead of the endless quizzes. Also, the textbook was dense and confusing to the point that I found it nearly incomprehensible. Luckily, the material was always on the problem sets and lectures and the problem set commentary provided enough instruction.
The huge lecture format is always a little tough, but the sections were productive and helpful.

I thought this class was designed and taught excellently. The weekly quizzes were, to my surprise, actually very helpful and useful in this class. While it wasn't the most exciting or engaging class, there's not much that be done to improve that given the subject matter. That being said, I thought Professor did a good job of making it as engaging as it could possibly be.

Strengths: The professor of this course is amazing. She is literally always willing to help, and she is so nice. She always tries to make our classes more entertaining. Some of the material was interesting too. I also loved the weekly quizzes because they really kept me on top of my work.
Weaknesses: The lecture component of the class was sometimes too much information thrown at us too quickly, and I often felt like I wouldn't understand a subject until I went to office hours and tried out the pset. Some of the material was also very dry and hard to comprehend.

This course has a lot of strengths but a lot of those were likely because of Professor Miller who was amazing. She constantly provided help and resources to make the content easier to understand. One weakness would likely be that it was not challenging enough.

The strengths of the course was that it was fascinating to learn what seemed to be a new language -- one that combined symbols and some kind of math and philosophy. Learning a new way of thinking -- a new way to break down what people say to see whether it is in fact logical -- was a great experience. A weakness of the course was the textbook we used. I do not think that it added much to the course and did not really think it was necessary as we went over most of the stuff in Goldfarb's book during class.

Professor Miller organized this course extraordinarily well. The weekly quiz structure was excellent for keeping me on top of the material. 

I wish we could have pushed a bit further conceptually.

The course moves at a very manageable pace. However, it at times felt too slow. I feel like the first half of the course could have been condensed into a few weeks, which would have left more time to explore quantificational deduction at the end.

I thought the resources offered to students were extraordinary in breadth, but that Professor Miller could've perhaps done a better job in moderating her explanations between the overly technical (towards which they often tended) and the overly simplifying use of metaphors etc. (which also occurred). However, she was incredibly committed and I don't think it would be even possible to ask for more - just some slight changes in methodology.

I thought this course was really great for the most part. It was intimidating at first, but Professor Miller is super supportive and does everything she can to help her students succeed. Section was useless, but I think that was because I had a last-minute TF who didn't know the material well or how to explain it. Basically, the class was conceptually hard, but once understood, pretty easy, and I think the key to that is finding people who can explain clearly and patiently.

Strengths: guaranteed to do well in the course if you keep up with the material on a weekly basis, instructions very clear, weekly quizzes very helpful so that you don't fall behind, lectures very well organized, section helpful to go over weekly psets.

I thought the format was actually wonderful, and would not change it. The quizzes ensured that we kept up with the (good deal) of course material, but were never tricky or punishing and I actually appreciated the opportunity to show what I'd learned throughout. Lectures were good, if sometimes boring (no fault to Dr. Miller, who did a great job with some dry material!) and section was very helpful, but good to be optional, as not always necessary.
I enjoyed the set up of weekly quizzes. Liked the time commitment this involved and enjoyed it better than problem sets.

Elizabeth Miller is a wonderful professor. She provides all the resources that students need to succeed in the course (if they have ample amounts of time to devote to the material, which I unfortunately did not). Her lectures are funny, clear, and cover all the ground necessary. My main problem with the course was the weekly quiz format. It was very overwhelming to learn so much material each week and then have to immediately display knowledge of it. Also, it was hard to miss a class each weekI think it would be better to have bi-weekly quizzes and use the extra class every other week as a review session or an opportunity to spread the material out and go into more depth with it.

I think the overall structure and setup of this course is very strong, though I think it is an extremely challenging task to make the material of this course interesting to people who don't naturally find it to be so.
It was difficult to learn material in lecture. I usually felt pretty behind everyone else. However, there were ample opportunities to get assistance in section and office hours
Perhaps the earlier parts of the course could be dealt with more quickly so as to allow time for a quiz on qualified deductions.

this class is phenomenal. miller cares more than ANY other teacher i've ever had about the students actually learning. we have weekly quizzes, which was AMAZING, because when the final rolls around, you've already mastered the material!

As it's taught, this class is pretty easy and could probably fit a lot more material in it. It's nonetheless a fun and interesting thing to do with your brain, and it's useful to students in pretty much any discipline, since everyone should know what arguments mean and how we use them.

STRENGTHS: Professor Miller is a wonderful professor, and she cares SO much about her students - she genuinely wants everyone to succeed, and will do everything she can to make it happen. She made every effort to make a (100+?) person lecture personal - for example, she called on almost everyone by their first name. She also made an amazing decision by choosing to give weekly quizzes - it made the material easy to follow, and made sure everyone kept up. The material is really interesting, no busywork at all, and the professor is quite possibly the kindest and most approachable professor at Yale.

WEAKNESSES: While Professor Miller was an engaging lecturer, I think that logic is a difficult course to teach through powerpoint and lecture. Even if you attend all the lectures, you really need to take the time to learn the material on your own.
I thought the structure of this course was very generous and was organized to help you succeed.
I think at times the course could move a little faster, but the pace did ensure that the content and concepts never felt ungraspable.

The strengths are definitely the format of the class and Prof. Miller. Weekly quizzes really force you to keep up with the material as you go along, which is especially important in a class like logic that directly builds upon the prior concept learned. Without the quizzes, I would not have been as invested in the class until exam time, which is sad to admit but true. Also, Prof. Miller is awesome!! Though I never interacted with her personally, the amount of care she has for her students is obvious. She makes herself readily available to everyone and that is incredible considering it is a large lecture class. She also goes out of her way to make students feel comfortable asking questions, or at the very least feeling comfortable with being lost. I have never had such an involved, caring professor in a lecture setting.
We had loads of opportunities to seek extra help if we needed, and I liked that the psets weren't graded (it allowed us to just focus on learning the material instead of worrying about grades).

I think all of the help afforded to students was very helpful because Professor Miller was very approachable and available to help any student with questions pertaining to any point in the course and also between section, office hours, and lecture, guidance was always provided.

Strengths: constant workload in terms of quizzes that forces you to stay on top of the material, solid (and ungraded) PSets, optional sections.

Weaknesses: readings are often difficult to get through (if still using Goldfarb's book) and the course often strays from what is in the textbook. Also can be easy to feel like you are slipping behind if lecture goes too quickly (as it sometimes does). 

I suggest finding a more digestible textbook going forward.

Elizabeth's kindness and energy was a huge strength of the course. Also, the flexibility was so nice -- optional section and problem sets took some of the pressure off, but really encouraged us to be responsible for our own learning and removed any aspect of busywork from the course. I think most people ended up doing the psets and many went to section anyway, but we only needed to do what would actually help us learn. I really appreciated that! A weakness of the course was that I never really got a sense of how First Order Logic was applicable in real life.

strengths: very good intro to logic, substantial covering of logical principles and key ideas

weaknesses: wish we could've covered other forms of logic than the two that we focused on in class.

This is a well-paced course and the material isn't impossible to grasp. If you put in some time, you will pass this class without a problem. However, lectures often went too fast to be understandable. A lot of stress for a class that wasn't stressfull.

The course was engaging and accessible for people with absolutely no background in logic! There were times when I got lost during lecture, or that it moved really quickly, which quickly set me on a spiral of "I don't understand this" to "why should I even bother to understand this." I loved the way the first few weeks upended our expectations of how English language works; I wish that carried through further in deduction and such.

The lectures and sections were extremely conducive to learning, so it seems like the readings were mostly as additional help. The psets are not graded but they are extremely useful since they prep you for weekly quizzes. The quizzes force you to understand the material, which gets exponentially harder as time goes on.

I loved the organisation of the class -- weekly quizzes and psets meant that it was really easy to stay on top of everything. Elizabeth Miller spend so much time giving so much attention and help to everyone. She's amazing.
More TAs!
Lectures were very fast-paced and did not really go in-depth. The p-sets were good for review, though.

This course is really well-organized. I loved the weekly quizzes because I felt that they helped me to keep up with the material and were a good self-check for how I felt I was doing. It was an excellent course.
Loved the weekly quizzes, wish that there was a quiz for the last unit to help me master it before the exam.

If you can think quantitatively at all (I haven't taken a real QR type class since high school but used to be good at math), then this is the QR for you!! It is so, so easy and can be quite interesting and fun. The format of a weekly quiz (70% of grade) and one final (30% of grade) works super well for continued student engagement. There is no work that you turn in (the psets are just practice for the quiz), which is great.

The course is incredibly well organized  Elizabeth is great, and clearly spends lots of time and energy to help students out. For every pset, for example, she answers detailed questions online, which is super helpful (I have no idea if this is standard or not  this was my first QR). The pace of the class requires you to stay on top of things (although I will say that the last few weeks with no quizzes allows you to fall off the wagon if you so choose to; not sure this is a weakness of the course, but rather something to be aware of if you'd been being motivated by the quizzes to stay on top of the material. There were some topics for which lecture wasn't super helpful  I'm thinking mostly of deduction with quantifiers. But that might just be the nature of the material  you kind of just have to sit with the material and mull it over, play with it, until it makes sense.

Strenghts: constant assessment forces you to keep up with the material. Sections are good and helpful. Consistent schedule helps manage the workload/studying.

Weknesses: lecture goes very fast and is sometimes makes non-confusing topics seem confusing because of the speed at which they are explained in lecture

The class covered the fundamentals of logic in a way that was comprehensive and expansive, and I liked having quizzes every week in order to make sure that I knew the material. I think sometimes we went a bit too fast in lectures, and I felt like I did not understand the material until I did the problem sets.
I wish it wasn't so test driven. The only reason my grade went down so much was because I caught the flu on finals weak and it dropped me a letter grade.

Lots of different ways to engage and strengthen your knowledge of the material-- weekly quizzes were super helpful as a way to keep up with the content, and the problem sets were also helpful. I found lecture and section and the readings (when I did them) less helpful, but I appreciated that there were lots of different directions available to tackle to content, for people with different learning styles.  
I didn't strictly mind it, but the material could have moved faster.

I can't think of a single weakness of this course as taught by Professor Miller. She is a clear and engaging lecturer who not only wants her students to exceed but specifically designed the course to make that happen. What you have to learn is straightforward and so is how to do so.

It is a good introduction to logic. A few areas of improvement include the time distribution for lectures and the way certain parts of the syllabus are taught, especially deductions. Sometimes lecture focused too much on giving various examples of application rather than clearly explaining underlying concepts.
I learned absolutely nothing from the lectures. They were incredibly difficult understand and I constantly had to go back to look at slides and review on my own.

Great class really geared towards learning and improving rather than harsh evaluations or competitive curves. The material did get more difficult as the class went on, but was extremely manageable if you put in the time to understand it.

I thought the format of the course worked wellthe weekly quizzes helped me keep up with the material, and the optional sections were useful for when you needed extra help. However, I felt like the pace of the lecture was sometimes offspending a lot of time on easier/more intuitive stuff and then speeding through difficult problems. Every time we learned something new I was really confused and then had to spend some time with the material alone before I finally understood it. I wish the lecture had moved more slowly on practice problems, because a lot of the material was very novel/unintuitive, so I often left lecture having no idea what had just happened.

Strengths - The online, ungraded PSETS were excellent for actually learning the material (without fear of failure and with instant feedback on whether or not you're getting a topic) and being prepared for quizzes.

The course is organized well and Professor Miller provides you with ample resources (i.e. office hours, additional notes, pdf versions of the power points, etc.) to ensure your success in the course. As for weaknesses, it could be argued that lectures can sometimes be difficult to follow. However, this doesn't happen often. This course is really strong.
Maybe just offer more one on one review and review in certain sections.

Crash course in the basics of formalized logic structures. Very interesting stuff, but also quite alien and unintuitive. The only thing that made the course and material accessible, endurable, and (most of the time) enjoyable was the inimitable Elizabeth Miller; we were truly some lucky ducks to have her as our instructor. Elizabeth was incredibly adept at explaining difficult concepts, and was always willing to go above and beyond to make sure we had what we needed to perform at our best, as a class and as individuals. My advice to anyone considering taking the class without Elizabeth is to be sure you enroll during a semester when there's a decent human being teaching it.
The material of the course becomes more complicated later in the semester, so more office hours are needed.
The combination of lecture help and section help made learning the material comfortable and less intimidating.
well-organised psets and weekly quizes, plenty of practices besides lectures, lots of supplementary materials

It is hard I think to yeah logic, as a lot of it is done and learned best by just reading it and figuring it out on your own. I think the pset website was fantastic and excellent. I also liked the quiz method. Overall it was a very fair course, and Elizabeth was a good lecturer.
The course is very structured, so I have no complaints about the lesson plan.  It is a solid intro course.
I loved this courseI thought it was a good balance of easy-going and challenging and thought it was set up for student success.

Goldfarb is fantastic

Lectures didnt really have much value-add to the course readings

Rationale for using this deduction system over other ones (that may have more closely modelled natural reasoning) was not clear

Having the psets be a smidge harder than the quizzes was great because I knew I was prepared for the quizzes when they came around. Also, being able to drop two is a good balance. The final exam was fine only because I could just ignore the part about the latest section (which was absolutely mechanical and rushed, but was the only weakness of the course).
well-organized and well-paced with helpful powerpoints and TAs

I think that this course has a lot of strengths a great professor, interesting content, and a format that makes it easy for you to do well. However, I think that some of the course policies were too lenient. The quizzes were very easy and the final exam was almost exactly the same as the practice exam. I think that some more intellectual challenge would benefit this class because oftentimes I felt like I could devote no time to it at all.
Set up to help students succeed.

Strengths: Structured syllabus, straight-forward (yet challenging) material, helpful problem sets, reasonable grading systems
Points of improvement: lectures could be restructured to explain material (problem example) more throughly (as opposed to simply fielding questions)

The format of the class is a major strength. The weekly quizzes keep you on top of the material -- you can't fall behind. Sections are optional but very helpful for doing the problem sets. The problem sets reinforced the material and weren't busy-work. On top of that, Professor Miller was endlessly caring and devoted to the course and to her students, and that made this class something more than a QR course for people who don't want to do math. This was a course in which people were invested in you learning and succeeding. I appreciated that.

The strengths of the class is the structure of the course, with weekly quizzes and sections, and the way in which the psets are organized to prepare students for assessments. One weakness of the course was that it was very hard to follow lecture.

The course material did escalate very much so in difficulty for me after Thanksgiving - while that is to be expected as we go into more challenging material, it was a bit difficult for me to adjust. I did appreciate the effort that was made to make this transition easier but I do think it might be possible to improve it a bit more e.g. pushing more of the quizzes back a few days.
I did not find the lectures to be engaging, though the professor was very sweet and supportive of us and I appreciated how devoted she was to answering students' questions on the problem sets.
Sometimes it was a little hard to hear the Professor during lecture.
This course could be taught with lectures that move at a slower pace.
Very thorough course

To be quite honest, I think most of the lectures did not facilitate my learning. Perhaps it's just the nature of the material. Or maybe I'm a very slow learner. But, most of the learning occurred on my own. It was very difficult to follow lectures, and it was clear that most of the class was as lost as I was. I do really appreciate the quizzes that we had every week. I dont know how I could have gotten by without them. I also appreciate the availability of Elizabeth and her approachability despite having such a large class.

This course will be too easy for people who have background in computer science or are "math" people. Everything that we learned can be understood though algorithms or mathematical equivalents. 

Strengths: the workload is aimed to help you understand the material. this is one of the few classes that if you do all of the work and show up to lecture you will most probably get a complete understanding of the lessons. 

Weaknesses: beware! this class attracts a lot of philosophy majors who need a QR credit! If thats you, then this course is amazing. If not, and you consider yourself to be pretty decent in stem fields, you may find this class to be too easy (and then sometimes boring).
Definitely recommend if you want to learn some cool info on logic. Plus it's really easy, minimal workload, just weekly quizzes which are really easy to get perfect scores on
Yes! Easy QR that is enjoyable and teaches you! You feel like you're learning.
Yes, definitely! But it took much more time than I thought -- like 6-8 hours a week.

It's a good QR  to take if you don't like traditional math - there are no numbers involved and it feels much more like a philosophy or english class than a math class. The weekly quizzes make it necessary to stay on top of the material and keep up with the psets, but it's a great class for a student who does not like high-pressure tests (no midterm!).

I definitely would. If you're willing to put in the work, this is a good QR class that will really teach you how to think carefully about how you structure your arguments. This is also a good class to take if you plan on taking the LSAT someday.
Yes, highly, especially if Professor Miller is teaching it.

I would recommend this course to another student because learning how to think and learning about how we speak was a very interesting and introspective experience. Learning a new language and breaking down arguments into a set of schema to see whether or not they are truth functional and if they imply the conclusion is sometimes fun. The course is like a big brain puzzle -- a gym for your mind where you exercise your brain to think about difficult scenarios, arguments, and questions.

Take this class for your QR. 

While Professor Miller will not be here anymore, the material of this class is such that you cannot make it hard, even if you taught it in a super unorganized way (which Professor Miller did not--she was excellent). At the same time, it is super fun! So it's the best of both worlds: you get a no-stress QR; and you get to do fun logic puzzles that really do get you to think systematically in a "QR" way. 

It's also helpful for understanding how arguments work.

The content of this course was honestly not particularly interesting. Once I got the hang of concepts some of them were actually kind of fun, but if you don't need it for the Philosophy major or as a distributional requirement I don't think it's interesting enough or relevant enough to real world arguments to be worth it. Elizabeth Miller was the real gem of this course, and she's leaving next year, so can't really speak to what it'll be like in the future.
QR gut. Take it if you need it. You don't have to go to lectures or do the reading
Yes. This is one of the easiest courses you could take at Yale. The grading is very lenient and

I would say that this course is exceptionally well-suited to first-years in the amount of support you receive, should you so desire. There were some problems with pacing of lectures, which was sometimes erratic, and you do have to do a good amount of steady work. I would absolutely take this class over intro Econ, which was far more boring. Because Professor Miller is leaving, I would suggest doing checking up on the class' new professor, because the grading scheme (one of the main reasons why the class was so easy) could easily change.
Absolutely! For anyone who needs a gut QR or is interested in discovering the foundations of logic. Might be very mechanical and boring for others.
Yes. It's a good QR for folks who don't love math, and I've genuinely enjoyed learning logic over the course of the smeester, not something I thought I'd be saying four months ago!
Would recommend if you are ready to learn the material by engaging with it on your own time. This does present a time commitment.
Yes, even if Elizabeth Miller isn't teaching. It's a solid, engaging, doable QR.
I would recommend this class to

If you are interested in formal study of logic, absolutely, If you need a QR credit, I think this is a relatively good choice as long as Professor Miller is still teaching it. If you don't fall into either of those two categories, probably not.
Yes, this course exposed me to a completely new field of study.
Absolutely. A great QR -- interesting, intellectually stimulating, but not too challenging.
Very much so, to anyone.

Yes, absolutely. While it unfortunately won't be taught by Professor Miller again, the material is inherently very interesting and useful. However, I will caution against taking this if you just want a gut QR - the course most likely will not be easy. Depending on your background and your general ability with this kind of stuff, the material can be extremely hard to digest. Unlike some other math courses (e.g. calculus) where you can just follow formulas, you REALLY have to understand the material in this course to do well. That said, it can be really rewarding, and I think everyone has the potential to understand it - it just may take a lot of time.
YES!!! Take this class ESPECIALLY if Elizabeth Miller is teaching it!

Yes. This was a great QR-credit for non-math students. Elizabeth really cares about her students and wants them to succeed. The workload is pretty low. Weekly quizzes count for 70% of the grade (you can drop the lowest two) and the final exam is 30%. Would recommend as an easy QR to humanities majors that don't want to do any math.
Absolutely. The course is doable and fun if you enjoy puzzley sort of things, but it is also not so easy that it feels like a waste of time, and manages to stay very interesting.
Yes!! Definitely take this with Prof. Miller. You will not only learn a ton but also have a strong support system for doing well. It is a challenging class but also very fun and rewarding.
Yes. This class is a blast, super interesting and relevant.
I would recommend this class, especially if you need a QR and don't like actual math.

Yes! I think it is a great QR requirement for anyone, especially people looking for an alternative to a straight math class. The professor was great and the material took time to process, but a lot of help was afforded to everyone to make sure everything was understood.

I would recommend this course. It is an atypical QR, especially if you are in need of a QR. It forces you to really grapple with what we mean when we say things and make arguments. Don't think that you can skip lecture or section and just do the quizzes, you really need to be there to get the material. Also always do the PSets.
It's ok, if you've done math or proofs before you'll get the hang of it.

I would recommend this course either if you think you will actually use First Order Logic, or if you want a QR credit and are ok with the fact that this isn't the most applicable subject matter in the real world.
yes, esp. those trying to get their feet wet with philosophy, or even critical thinking and reasoning, for that matter.

This is a good QR for non-STEM majors because it's a lot more applicable to what you will be doing in your other classes and not very heavy. Beware, though, this is not a gut. I came in thinking it would be and had to do a good amount of work to keep up. But it's in no way impossible.

Absolutely. First Order Logic is the perfect QR credit for a humanities major. It actually gives us something useful to our discipline by teaching you how to construct valid arguments and making you think critically about logic in general. Its structure is also great for those of us who are used to essay-based classes and find PSets to be tedious.

I would recommend this course to a student who is looking for a QR credit, or looking for a logical-conceptual background to use in computer science or law. It was light, occasionally fun, and engaging, but I don't anticipate needing these skills that much in the future.

I would recommend this course to students, but not to all. I think if you're interested in logic, arguments, etc., then take this class. If not, the material can be very dry, but intuitive for the most part.
Yes!!! A fun, great QR. It's hard, but rewarding. Elizabeth is amazing.

Yes, Take It! Its not easy but the class is set up for you to be successful. Just apply yourself and make sure you are using the resources. Don't be afraid to ask for help! This coming from a non-stem major.
Yes
Yes! Especially for a non-stem major looking for a QR credit.
Yes- absolutely.
Yes I would, it is a great way to get a QR credit that isn't math, but still critical thinking.
It is the perfect fairly interesting easy QR!
I would recommend this course to any student who enjoys deductive reasoning or may be curious to see what logic is.
I would not recommend this to a student who is not considering doing philosophy. Although the workload is essentially nothing, it can be very difficult to grasp many topics discussed in this course.

I would recommend this course, obviously to all philosophy students who need to take it, but also to anyone who's looking for a helpful and easy QR. It's not a 'gut' in that you need to put in the work to understand it, but it is extremely manageable and not a high workload at all.
Yes
Yes. It is interesting, engaging, and useful.
First order logic is a great, straightforward and low stress way to tackle your QR credit.
Regardless of whether you are interested in going further in philosophy, this course provides useful and transferable skills. Elizabeth Miller is also amazing.

TAKE THIS COURSE WITH PROFESSOR MILLER! I loved this class! As an English major, it was an awesome way to workout a part of my brain that has been sadly neglected since my high school calculus days. It was clear what we had to learn and how to learn it. Professor Miller has a lot of resources to help students and is very accessible. She always responded to my emails thoroughly and quickly. The weekly quizzes were a really good way to make sure you understood that week's material. Plus, you can drop your two lowest quiz scores and the quizzes mean your grade isn't all based on two tests. I actually had fun in this class and looked forward to doing the optional problem sets. (You should do them because the quizzes are based on them.)
Even if you are not a philosophy major, I would recommend it if you are looking for an interesting subject area to look into.
I would not recommend to others unless they have a strong passion for the subject. Otherwise it is not worth the hassle.

Highly recommended for students looking to dip their toes into logic, especially as the basis of many mathematical and computer science algorithms. Truth tables and basic logical knowledge are great in developing valid philosophical argumentation and understanding the relationship between natural language arguments and symbolically notated arguments.

It's a good QR credit if you don't want to do math, but be aware that the material might not always come easily, so you have to put in some time with it. Also, the material is kind of irrelevant, but it does feel like you're exercising your brain and using it in new ways, which can be rewarding.
YES! If you need a QR, this is one of your best bets.

Absolutely, especially if it's with Professor Miller. The material is fascinating and offers you a more nuanced understanding of rhetoric and the ways in which the form of statements can be used as instruments of persuasion. The course is well structured and Professor Miller was deeply invested in the individual success of each of her students, and it showed in all the resources she provided us with. If you're lost and seek out help, Professor Miller and/or the TAs will make sure everything makes sense before a quiz. All in all, an amazing class and one that I would honestly recommend to everyone.
Yes! This is a fun QR credit for those who dont want to take a math class. Its challenging but manageable.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students because the work is challenging but the instructors want you to succeed and the subject matter is definitely interesting and could help in numerous other subjects.

Crash course in the basics of formalized logic structures. Very interesting stuff, but also quite alien and unintuitive. The only thing that made the course and material accessible, endurable, and (most of the time) enjoyable was the inimitable Elizabeth Miller; we were truly some lucky ducks to have her as our instructor. Elizabeth was incredibly adept at explaining difficult concepts, and was always willing to go above and beyond to make sure we had what we needed to perform at our best, as a class and as individuals. My advice to anyone considering taking the class without Elizabeth is to be sure you enroll during a semester when there's a decent human being teaching it.
Yes, this course made me a better thinker and made a marked impact on all of my learning.
It depends: if you've taken logic in high school math, it's not necessarily likely that you can learn a lot of new things

I would recommend r to anyone who wants to think a bit more about how the things we say every day break down logically. This is very much an intro course, and you dont get down to arguments and deductions until the very end, so be prepared to take other, higher level courses later if you really want to get into arguments and logical reasoning through arguments.
Yes. The course was very interesting, even if you aren't studying the subject.
Yes! I loved this course.
Yes!! Logic is so important

100% yes. This class was a relatively easy QR credit, but the real gem of the class was Elizabeth. By the second week of class, she could call on people by name in a 150-person+ lecture, and was always holding extra office hours to make sure everyone in the class understood what was happening. She has definitely inspired me to take more logic classes in the future.
take it if you need a manageable qr credit but you actually have to work for your grade
I would recommend this course to another student if they are looking for a QR credit that is not too intense it was interesting and definitely not intense.

Yes, especially if a well-organized and sturdy course structure is appealing to you. This course offers a clear (yet challenging) path to understanding basic logic. If you commit yourself to the reasonable work the course requires, it will be rewarding.

Yes, if you have no background in STEM and need a QR, the professor creates a learning environment with enough resources for you to excel if you put in the time though some concepts may seem difficult at first.

Logic was a great QR. It's not too difficult, but it's also not pointless. It's one of those classes that makes you think in new ways, and that is extremely valuable. The weekly quiz format might seem daunting, but it is manageable and it really helps you stay on top of things. The workload is not overwhelming at all, but this doesn't feel like a mindless gut, either. If you need a QR but don't want to do math, or if you just want a class that presents puzzles and shows you how to solve them, take Logic.
Yes, it was a different course that was challenging but rewarding.
Yes - I thought the class really was a supportive and welcoming environment and all the instructors were incredibly helpful.

I would not necessarily recommend this course to another student. I needed it to fulfill my QR credit but honestly I think you could probably find a better option if that's what you're looking for. I didn't find the lectures to be engaging at all, and found the class overall very frustrating and demoralizing.
I would recommend this course to anyone who has an interest in the study of arguments.
Yes if they needed a QR requirement and wanted to hone their logic skills.
Yes, I would recommend, although Elizabeth won't be teaching again.
If you are someone who has a pretty strong math background or has dabbled in CS, then this course will be easy and probably won't challenge you
